citeinfo.title: Regions of Known or Potential Geothermal Resources
citeinfo.othercit: Renewable Energy and Power Technology - Pat Laney

descript.abstract: This coverage shows areas favorable for discovery and development of low-temperature (lower than 100°C) geothermal resources. They are defined on the basis of thermal springs, thermal wells, and ground-water, geologic and geophysical surveys. These gray areas are modified, in the light of later information, from those shown in the U.S. Geological Survey Circular 790 (Muffler, 1979). Existing knowledge does not in general permit the inference that thermal waters may be found everywhere within the depicted areas, nor do the boundaries represent certain knowledge of the areal extent of the geothermal resources. The boundaries are subject to change as new information is obtained.
descript.purpose: Provides a visual representation of existing geothermal resources and potiential areas for residential and commerical direct use applications.
descript.supplinf: This data layer is shown on a map in conjuction with land ownership and spring and well temperatures.

idinfo.useconst: This data set is provided "as-is" without warranty of any kind, including, but not limited to, the implied warranties of merchantability and fitness for a particular purpose. The user assumes all responsibility for the accuracy and suitability of this data set for a specific application. In no event will the INEEL Spatial Analysis Laboratory and/or the Idaho National Engineering and Environmental Laboratory (INEEL) are liable for any damages, including lost profits, lost savings, or other incidental or consequential damages arising from the use of or inability to use this data set.

cntinfo.cntinst: In order to generate updates to this data layer a formal request must be submitted to Pat Laney at the INEEL Renewable Energy & Power Technology

idinfo.native: Microsoft Windows XP Version 5.1 (Build 2600) Service Pack 3; ESRI ArcCatalog 9.3.1.3000

dataqual.logic: Polygon topology present. Every polygon has a label and all polygons are closed.

citeinfo.title: Regions of Known or Potential Geothermal Resources
citeinfo.othercit: Renewable Energy and Power Technology - Pat Laney

srcinfo.srccontr:
Map Title: Geothermal Resources of Arizona, 1982
Geothermal data compiled and interpreted by James C. Witcher, Claudia Stone, W. Richard Hahman, Sr. of the State of Arizona Bureau of Geology and Mineral Technology, A Division of the University of Arizona, Tucson Map prepared by the National Geophysical and Solar-Terrestrial Data Center National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration for the Division of Geothermal Energy United States Department of Energy Alaska E Series Map National geodetic vertical datum of 1929 Modified transverse mercator projection Base map supplied by U.S. Geological Survey Topographic maps scale 1:250,000 and other official sources 1927 North American Datum Lambert conformal conic projection based on standard parallels 33° and 45°

procstep.procdesc: The original maps were registered on a digitizer tablet and the identified thermal waters polygons were digitized. A polygon coverage was generated and projected. Once the layer was drawn on a map and reviewed with other geothermal feature, such as spring and well temperature data, the polygons were modified by heads-up digitizing on the screen based on drawings provided by the Renewable Energy and Power Technology group.

stdorder.ordering: Written data request (e-mail or letter) must be received specifying exactly what the data will be used for along with a charge number to fill the request. Requestor must also specify the projection and datum information, as well as the digital format type (ie. .e00, shape file, AutoCAD DXF). Once request has been approved for external release the data will be exported into requestors desired GIS data format along with the INEEL Spatial Analysis Laboratory disclaimer.
